body: Not sure if it would matter - but ids are effectively (if not outright) immutable - the output string could be created on instantiation of the id so that concatenation / formatting would not need to occur on every log statement - the toString would just return a fixed string of the instance.

> LGTM - maybe @DomGarguilo can give a once over to see if there would be changes w.r.t. junit 5.

There will be changes since TemporaryFolder was removed in junit 5 but these changes look good and it wont be a difficult transition in these cases that were changed.
Coincidentally, FateIT also passed in those two runs.

>  I don't think it is a big of deal anymore to have the toString() method return a formatted string. I think most places it is used is in string concatenation and logging.

If the majority use of toString is for logging then maybe the simplest thing is to make toString format its return. There may be user facing outputs from utilities/shell that we may want to handle differently, if those are a minority then maybe they could just call canonical().

> Coincidentally, FateIT also passed in those two runs.

True. However, it failed locally for me several times after this got merged. It's definitely unrelated. Can discuss on #2474

So far it seems like there are three viable options (with the log4j specific option not being viable) 

- Modify toString() on AbstractId to format the id and include a type
  - Cons: have to find all places where this is not suitable and change to canonical().  Could lead to errors when constructing metadata table entries and ZK/DFS paths.
  - Pros: New code written that logs the id will automatically use the formatted id.  For user facing output devs usually test that when writing it and if they don;t like toString() output they can switch to canonical().
- Add a new method to AbstractId to format the id and include a type.
   - Cons: Have to modify all existing logging to call new method.  Have to remember to use the new method when writing new logging stmts.
   - Pros: canonical() and toString() are the same, the more I think about this not a huge pro.
- Do nothing
  - Cons : Logging does consistently include type w/ id.
  - Pros: So easy to do.

I think having toString different from canonical is error prone. People will make mistakes, and not realize... whether it's concatenating a path in ZK, constructing a metadata entry, or just an innocuous log statement, mistakes will occur, and they will not be easy to detect, because toString is not explicit in string concatenation, it's merely implied.

However, ultimately, I don't think it's necessary to bother with trying to format the toString for table IDs and namespace IDs. Most of the time when we want to log, we want to log the table / namespace, not just the table ID / namespace ID. I would prefer to have a concrete type for Table and Namespace, whose toString is a formatted representation of both the name and its ID. I'd much rather see something like `deleting TABLE[NAME=mytable;ID=2c]` than `deleting TABLEID(2c)`.

>  People will make mistakes, and not realize... whether it's concatenating a path in ZK, constructing a metadata entry

That is a really good con. I edited my earlier comment to add it.

> However, ultimately, I don't think it's necessary to bother with trying to format the toString for table IDs and namespace IDs. Most of the time when we want to log, we want to log the table / namespace, not just the table ID / namespace ID. I would prefer to have a concrete type for Table and Namespace, whose toString is a formatted representation of both the name and its ID. I'd much rather see something like deleting TABLE[NAME=mytable;ID=2c] than deleting TABLEID(2c).

That would be really nice.  I would love to see something like `TABLE[NAME=mytable;ID=2c]` consistently in the logs.  Is there an issue for that?  If we open an issue for that, then we could probably close this.  I don't think there is anything general to do.  If we create a new  FateTxID type then how it logs can be tailored specifically for it, but there is nothing more general to do in the code base for other id types.

In JUnit 5, the assert statements can accept a `Supplier<String>` as an alternative to `String` for the message to supply if the assert fails. For example:
```java
    Supplier<String> message = () -> "Calculator.add(2, 2) test failed";
    assertEquals(3, Calculator.add(2, 2), message);
```
or equivalently 
```java
    assertEquals(3, Calculator.add(2, 2), () -> "Calculator.add(2, 2) test failed");
```
This has the benefit of being lazily evaluated so the string will only be created when the message is needed rather than always being created. I am wondering if this possible performance gain is worth the possible (small) decrease in readability/increase in code complexity. This could be something we standardize while the migration of JUnit 4 to 5 takes place since we need to change the order of the assert parameters when there is a message anyways.


Anyone have any thoughts on this?

Are there issues with these files being in the jar? 
log4j2-test.properties
shellit.shellit
I have no idea what that second file is so not sure what to do with it.
I like this way of doing it. The message will only get created when needed and I don't think the code becomes much less readable.

The vast vast vast majority of JUnit assert statements are trivial and obvious, and don't need a special message at all, because the message that JUnit itself provides is more than sufficient. Even if the extra time for each string took 100ms per test (which I think is an overestimate), that's only a single extra minute on a more than 4 hour build. Even if they took half a second each, that's still only 5 minutes extra on a more than 4 hour build.

Don't bother. It's almost certainly not worth it.

It is a test so readability and maintainability should have priority.  There is no way that any optimization of a string that is executed once during a test is going to make any difference.  Something like needing repeatedly spin up a minicluser needs to be evaluated. The time to build a log message is not something to worry about.

If it makes migration easier - pick whatever is easiest to understand in terms of the test context.

I'd have to mine through tickets to see if there's a current issue for it. I know it was a part of the set of ideas I had for the 2.0 API, to have a concrete Table and Namespace object, as well as part of the recent work I had been looking into about standardizing how we pass table information over RPCs (as name or id). I think Table and Namespace formatting would be covered by that, but this issue might still apply to other kinds of identifiers.
Thanks for feedback. I wont bother using the supplier. Seems like plain old `String` is sufficient.

> Are there issues with these files being in the jar?
> 
> log4j2-test.properties

This one might be tricky to move. I'm not sure. We're probably relying on it being in a default location, for log4j to pick it up automatically. However, that's probably also controllable with a system property we can set in the surefire/failsafe config.

> shellit.shellit
> I have no idea what that second file is so not sure what to do with it.

This can be moved. It actually looks like another one that doesn't actually need to be put into the jar. The ShellIT reads it directly from src/main/resources , and it looks like it does that in order to test executing a file with Accumulo shell commands.

I think this is pretty much finished aside from some dependency related issues. The build is failing from a "used-undeclared" error within `accumulo-start` module. I think this is happening because the tests that have not been converted to JUnit 5 tests should be running on the junit vintage-engine dependency however, since junit 4 is part of the `org.apache.hadoop:hadoop-client-minicluster:jar:3.3.0` (which is in the accumulo-start pom), it is using the junit 4 dependency instead and complaining that vintage-engine is **not used but declared** and junit 4 is **used but undeclared**. I'm not too sure how this can be handled aside from somehow ignoring the warnings for now and converting to junit 5.

> I'm not too sure how this can be handled aside from somehow ignoring the warnings for now and converting to junit 5.

The warnings will cause the build to fail, so they should be suppressed. This can be done in the pom.xml section that configures the dependency analyzer. You can just leave a brief XML comment above the suppression explaining when it can be removed.
This is a nice enhancement. I was just reading about Sealed classes in JDK 17 and wondering how we can use them, perhaps in our API or SPI.
What version of Hadoop are you seeing the changes to `WritableUtils`? I did a quick diff across several versions and that class hasn't changed (other than javadoc) from 2.6.5 to 3.3.0.

Using 08:59:11 ~$ java -version openjdk version "17.0.1" 2021-10-19 OpenJDK Runtime Environment (build 17.0.1+12-Ubuntu-120.04) OpenJDK 64-Bit Server VM (build 17.0.1+12-Ubuntu-120.04, mixed mode, sharing) I am unable to build using maven. I cleaned out my local m2 repository and that didn't help. 
[ERROR] Error executing Maven.
[ERROR] java.lang.IllegalStateException: Unable to load cache item
[ERROR] Caused by: Unable to load cache item
[ERROR] Caused by: Could not initialize class com.google.inject.internal.cglib.core.$MethodWrapper
Caused by: java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: Could not initialize class com.google.inject.internal.cglib.core.$MethodWrapper Update: Looks like Maven 3.8.X is required for java 17. I am currently on Maven 3.6.3

> What version of Hadoop are you seeing the changes to `WritableUtils`? I did a quick diff across several versions and that class hasn't changed (other than javadoc) from 2.6.5 to 3.3.0.

There isn't a change to WritableUtils. I'm just trying to avoid the compressed byte array implementation, because it uses GZip, and that's expensive and unnecessary for password-sized byte arrays, and GZip itself has changed in Java between Java 11 and 17 (something in the header changed in the compressed format, so the bytes can differ in the compressed format, but the compressed value is still decompress-able to the same original value).

> Update: Looks like Maven 3.8.X is required for java 17. I am currently on Maven 3.6.3

I didn't even notice. I've been using 3.8.4 since it was released. Glad you found the cause and fix.

> I'm just trying to avoid the compressed byte array implementation, because it uses GZip, and that's expensive and unnecessary for password-sized byte arrays, and GZip itself has changed in Java between Java 11 and 17

Ah OK, cool. I will take another look at the serialization.

> > I'm just trying to avoid the compressed byte array implementation, because it uses GZip, and that's expensive and unnecessary for password-sized byte arrays, and GZip itself has changed in Java between Java 11 and 17
> 
> Ah OK, cool. I will take another look at the serialization.

The unit test ensures that it can successfully read the old format, one made by Java 11, and the other made by Java 17, slightly different due to GZip.

https://github.com/apache/accumulo/pull/2500/files#diff-0f11b1b762308d552a46a013fe102aa981da06f8dd04c521a9c30469ad65750aR57-R58

Here are some quick notes that might help to reference for those who work on the migration or for reviewers.

| JUnit4  | JUnit5  |
| ----------- | ----------- |
| `@Test` | `@Test` |
| `@Before` | `@BeforeEach` |
| `@After` | `@AfterEach` |
| `@BeforeClass` | `@BeforeAll` |
| `@AfterClass` | `AfterAll` |
| `@Ignore` | `@Disable` |
| `@Category` | `@Tag` |

| | JUnit4  | JUnit5  |
| ----------- | ----------- | ----------- |
| Testing class package | `org.junit` | `org.junit.jupiter.api` |
| Assertions class | `Assert` | `Assertions` |

`TemporaryFolder` was removed and instead a `File` or `Path` is used in JUnit5 with the `@TempDir` annotation.

Additionally, the order of parameters in assert statements has changed. The optional message is now the last parameter rather than the first parameter. e.g. `assertTrue("should be equal", 1==3)` becomes `assertTrue(1==3, "should be equal")`

I've marked this PR as ready for review. I know that there is a lot to look through when reviewing so I thought it might be helpful to leave some notes to help reviewers know what they are looking at.

> 
> Here are some quick notes that might help to reference for those who work on the migration or for reviewers.
> 
> | JUnit4  | JUnit5  |
> | ----------- | ----------- |
> | `@Test` | `@Test` |
> | `@Before` | `@BeforeEach` |
> | `@After` | `@AfterEach` |
> | `@BeforeClass` | `@BeforeAll` |
> | `@AfterClass` | `AfterAll` |
> | `@Ignore` | `@Disable` |
> | `@Category` | `@Tag` |
> 
> | | JUnit4  | JUnit5  |
> | ----------- | ----------- | ----------- |
> | Testing class package | `org.junit` | `org.junit.jupiter.api` |
> | Assertions class | `Assert` | `Assertions` |
> 
> `TemporaryFolder` was removed and instead a `File` or `Path` is used in JUnit5 with the `@TempDir` annotation.
>
>Additionally, the order of parameters in assert statements has changed. The optional message is now the last parameter rather than the first parameter. e.g. `assertTrue("should be equal", 1==3)` becomes `assertTrue(1==3, "should be equal")`

```

@milleruntime Were you waiting on anything else before merging?

> @milleruntime Were you waiting on anything else before merging?

No, I was looking into some other improvements. I am attempting to split up ShellServerIT into multiple tests. I am tempted to make 50 ITs from it haha.

> * Create ShellCreateTableIT from tests moved from ShellServerIT

What's different about those tests that necessitated being separate?

> * Modify ShellServerIT to not delete tables after ever test

It's probably fine either way, but what motivated this change? Is this going to be a problem in resource-constrained environments, because all the tests are using the same Mini?

Did you just move tests around, or delete you delete any? I didn't get to do a thorough review, but I got the impression that a lot was deleted, and not necessary as much created.

These ITs are passing for me

The total time overall is the same. Hopefully these changes make it easier to debug individual tests. I had a hard time debugging one of the tests in ShellServerIT and it took a while to run the whole IT. For example, now they each get their own directory in mini. I would prefer lots of small tests that take less than a minute to run. Even with this change, ShellServerIT still have ~50 tests in it so I might split out another IT since that is a lot for one IT. One idea I had was to put all the tests that are testing a simple command in one and the rest (which do more complicated things) in another IT.

@ctubbsii are you familiar with the test `scansWithClassLoaderContext` in ShellServerIT ? This seems to be the only test that can't be run by itself in IntelliJ. It is checking if a class is already on the classpath but it will throw an exception if it is already. I was thinking this could just clean the class from the classpath if it detects it but wasn't sure how to do that.

@dlmarion @keith-turner I noticed a shared static method between 2 separate FATE operations that was added in this PR and was wondering if this could cause concurrency problems. https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/3b2cdb99aeb60dfcc58eba26b6620825aadb560b/server/manager/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/manager/tableOps/compact/cancel/CancelCompactions.java#L67

I am not sure of what the situation would be but the fact that these two operations mutate the same node in ZK (compact-cancel-id) makes me curious. If they are both running and hit ZK problems, I wonder if a cancel compaction may cause a delete table to fail.
Delete Table (PreDeleteTable)
Cancel compaction (CancelCompactions)
synchronizing this method shouldn't hurt
Was there a problem observed with this code?  I ask because ZooReaderWriter. mutateExisting() is used by the code and that already offers concurrency protection. So curious why more is needed.

> @keith-turner - you are saying that because of the table locks?

I am asking because the call `zoo.mutateExisting(...)` should properly handle two concurrent threads attempting to modify the same ZK node.  So I am curious what problem synchronizing the method solves that the call to  `zoo.mutateExisting(...)` does not already address.

Yeah, I deleted my comment when I re-read yours and looked at the code. I'm not sure if it was a problem, I think it was something that @milleruntime saw looking at the code. I can revert easily enough. Waiting to hear from @milleruntime
I was more concerned about what happens with ZK problems and 2 separate operations trying to modify the same exact node.

> > @keith-turner - you are saying that because of the table locks?
> 
> I am asking because the call `zoo.mutateExisting(...)` should properly handle two concurrent threads attempting to modify the same ZK node. So I am curious what problem synchronizing the method solves that the call to `zoo.mutateExisting(...)` does not already address.

Are you saying that the way that method is written it should handle concurrent modifications?

> I was more concerned about what happens with ZK problems and 2 separate operations trying to modify the same exact node.

If there is a problem with that, then its a bigger problem because many places in the code use mutateExisting.

> Are you saying that the way that method is written it should handle concurrent modifications?

Yeah it hopefully should.  The mutateExisting code gets the stat from ZK when it reads the node and when it writes back out to ZK it passes the stat version.  If the version has changes, then ZK should throw an exception causing the mutate operation to retry.

https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/48e31af4962660dd1c09054cd5128a30f86b3c71/core/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/fate/zookeeper/ZooReaderWriter.java#L182-L195

If the added sync is not fixing any problems, then it has the potential to cause problems.  Since its a static sync it can cause FATE txs that are completely unrelated to each other to wait on each other.

> If the added sync is not fixing any problems, then it has the potential to cause problems. Since its a static sync it can cause FATE txs that are completely unrelated to each other to wait on each other.

What about sync'ing on an object? TableId maybe?

> What about sync'ing on an object? TableId maybe?

Sure, could have more granular sync. But why is it needed?

Based on something @ctubbsii said the other day, I wonder if ZooKeeper.sync() should be called when BADVERSION is encountered. See the note at https://zookeeper.apache.org/doc/r3.6.3/zookeeperProgrammers.html#ch_zkGuarantees.
I think these imply that the Compactor process is running faster than the test code for some reason.
It may also be the case that the Compactor from the previous test was not actually stopped from the call in `tearDown`.

> I think these imply that the Compactor process is running faster than the test code for some reason.

That's kinda what I was thinking.

> It may also be the case that the Compactor from the previous test was not actually stopped from the call in `tearDown`.

Wouldn't it be likely running on a different port? Or using a unique ID for the compaction task for each test, if it's reusing the same cluster?

The test code is not communicating with the Compactor. I think what I can do is have each test use a different compaction queue. Then, if a Compactor is running from a previous test for some reason, it won't pick up the compaction. I'll start on that change now. Is ExternalCompaction2_IT the only one currently failing?

> @ctubbsii are you familiar with the test `scansWithClassLoaderContext` in ShellServerIT ? This seems to be the only test that can't be run by itself in IntelliJ. It is checking if a class is already on the classpath but it will throw an exception if it is already. I was thinking this could just clean the class from the classpath if it detects it but wasn't sure how to do that.

Sorry, not off the top of my head, I'm not familiar. I'd have to investigate.

> Is ExternalCompaction2_IT the only one currently failing

It's the only one I saw to motivate this issue, but it wouldn't hurt to make all of them use unique queue names, like we do generally with unique table names in all our ITs.

> Based on something @ctubbsii said the other day, I wonder if ZooKeeper.sync() should be called when BADVERSION is encountered. See the note at https://zookeeper.apache.org/doc/r3.6.3/zookeeperProgrammers.html#ch_zkGuarantees.

My guess would be doing that could possibly make mutateExisting loop less in the case of concurrent updates (and therefore possibly perform better?).  I don't think its needed for correctness though.  Knowing if its worthwhile for performance seems tricky because sync() read may be more expensive, so is that offset by possibly looping less.
So, am I reverting this commit?

> However, you may wish to rename TestShell, because it currently will get picked up as a test class for unit tests, as it matches the default naming patterns for maven-surefire-plugin.

Oh good catch. I will rename it.

If this is referring to calling sync in the test, then never mind.  

However, w.r.t ZooKeeper consistency - it seems that needing to force consistency across clients may highlight a design issue.  I think that it would be preferable from a performance standpoint if we could design for and handle eventual consistency. 

Event notification will always be asynchronous - even two clients connected to the same ZK server will receive notifications at slightly different times. Designing for that seems to be the more robust option.

It seems that the sync would increase the load on the leader - how much?  Would it matter - a large cluster already keeps ZooKeeper really busy - would these "extra" syncs cause performance issues?  It may be that because this is dealing with FATE ops - those have a relatively low frequency - maybe a few or at most 10's of operations per second that the extra cost would not be measurable.
Created https://github.com/apache/accumulo/pull/2507

> So, am I reverting this commit?

I would be in favor of that, unless there is a problem it fixes.  The static lock can cause contention.

> > So, am I reverting this commit?
> 
> I would be in favor of that, unless there is a problem it fixes. The static lock can cause contention.

Sounds like it would be better to revert to prevent lock contention but I am not sure what @EdColeman is saying about ZK.
@milleruntime - it was due to a hypothesis that compactors from other tests were not being shut down as they should be and interfering with the current test.

Apparently my assumption that the QATCodec could read data written by the GzipCodec is incorrect. The `qzip` utility can read/write `gzip` compatible files, but it looks like the QAT-based codec works differently. Details at https://github.com/Intel-bigdata/IntelQATCodec/issues/33.
Closing w/out merging, see #2219 for details.

It appears that the balancer is getting called for each tablet, hence why so many repetitive messages. This was supposed to be fixed with the creation of a new class `ThrottledBalancerProblemReporter` in #1891 but it doesn't look like the reporting is working properly.
@brianloss any interest in taking a look at this issue?
I saw this TODO in the code. https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ACCUMULO-2938

@keith-turner I ran into a dependency snag. The FateCommand uses a bunch of Fate types and is in the Shell package. Moving the Fate stuff to manager, breaks this. I don't know of a good solution other than rewrite `FateCommand` and make new types that use API. Any ideas?

Are you suggesting that the log statement in `FateLogger` include the prop_? Beyond that, the log statements do vary quite a bit. 

```
zoostore /accumulo/c1103b36-2a1b-42c2-90e0-27e1bc895a6b/fate/tx_60ab6ecd10fcdfed/prop_debug [83, 32, 67, 114, 101, 97, 116, 101, 84, 97, 98, 108, 101] OVERWRITE
```
vs what is in FateLogger: 

```
setProperty FATE[60ab6ecd10fcdfed] debug CreateTable
```

A small change to include more info on what debug stands for in the latter log message could be useful.
Looks like the build is failing due to formatting issues. Can you rune `mvn clean package -DskipTests` locally and then push up the changes from that. That will run the formatter.

I am not quite sure. Are you adding the changes before pushing them up (no need for a force push)? 

It seems the specific issue is in `KerberosRenewalIT` and is a very small spacing issue in a comment.

I've added all changes and pushed them,

The 'package' command seems to throw an error :

Yeah, appears to be an issue due to Windows. I went ahead and added a commit that fixes the tiny format issue.
Thanks :)

All the ITs passed with the changes so far. I saw a few tests flake out a bit, because they were timing sensitive and the operation they were waiting on took slightly longer than expected, but they passed on subsequent runs. And, I think that happened because I had another build running on the same machine at the same time. I couldn't reproduce those failures.

If you don't get to my suggestions above first, I may just make them myself, and merge this in. I don't want to risk this PR diverging further from the current passing state, with all the ITs passing and risking my absurdly time-consuming code review I just did on these 250 or so files getting stale. :smiley_cat:
This change broke `org.apache.accumulo.test.functional.DeleteRowsIT.testManyRows`, and I'm not sure why. This may need to be reverted until it is solved.
As for building on Windows, we definitely don't support that, but you can probably get it to work if you build in a terminal on Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL).

> but it's not working

Can you explain what's not working? What problem did you encounter?

While running maven task `checkstyle:check` an error is thrown:
`
Element type "property" must be followed by either attribute specifications, ">" or "/>".
`
I think it come from the Regex itself but not sure.

When i change the regex i have an other error saying that class `RegexpStringToStringConcatenation` can't be instantiated. I'm not very good at maven task, i'm usually using Gradle :)
I will look into it when I get the chance. Feel free to revert if I don't get to it in time.
Okay, I'll revert it then, because I don't want it to hold up other changes, but it should be simply to re-apply once the problem is discovered. I'll re-open the original issue to track it.

I reverted the change in PR #2397 in 664b5a5dd137a58e4df47915c8f5f209a530cd8a because it caused a reproducible test failure in DeleteRowsIT, and it needs further work before applying. I'm re-opening this issue so it can be investigated, fixed, and the patch (with fixes) re-applied.

Try this one:

```xml
                <module name="RegexpSinglelineJava">
                  <!-- double escape quotes because checkstyle passes these through another xml parser -->
                  <property name="format" value="&quot; [+] &quot;" />
                  <property name="message" value="Unnecessary concatenation of string literals" />
                </module>
```
That was it thanks :D !
There are two approvals - my previous suggestions could be done as a follow on if this is merged as is.
This was inspired by PR #2484. I think it achieves a similar goal.
I added more rigorous checks for unexpected non-ASCII characters in #2514 to catch potentially dangerous occurrences, so we can leave these non-harmful ones alone.

> There are two approvals - my previous suggestions could be done as a follow on if this is merged as is.

@KikiManjaro - there is another form suggested by @ctubbsii that may be even cleaner to read using Duration.ofHours, Minutes,...(x).toMillis()
```
Duration.ofHours(24).toMillis()
```

> @KikiManjaro - there is another form suggested by @ctubbsii that may be even cleaner to read using Duration.ofHours, Minutes,...(x).toMillis()
> ```
> Duration.ofHours(24).toMillis()
> ```

There might be subtle differences in overflow behavior between those that probably won't matter, but might be worth paying close attention just in case. If I remember correctly, most lines are shorter with TimeUnit, even more so if you static import the type, as in `HOURS.toMillis(24)`, but Duration might be better in some cases. Duration might also use more object creation whereas TimeUnit is an enum, basically a bag of singletons.

Seems the issue is the if statement is true so it throws the RuntimeException. Which doesn't exit the test but rather slows things down due to the retries. This eventually causes the test to timeout. I can get a fix out next weekend though if someone else wants to tackle it in the meantime, feel free.
